UpgradeExperienceDialog.Subtext: Windows Admin Center has been updated from {0} to {1}
UpgradeExperienceDialog.Title: Windows Admin Center has been updated!

Page2.Subtext: We are building on and improving Windows Admin Center, but we need your help to make sure it’s the best it can be. Click the link under the help section to send us feedback or suggestions. We look forward to hearing from you!
Page2.Title: Help us build the future of Computer management

Page1.Subtext: Windows Admin Center is a new web-based management solution from Microsoft, built to modernize and simplify administration of your Windows datacenter.
Page1.Title: Welcome to Windows Admin Center

Completed.description: CredSSP server has been successfully disabled.
Completed.message: Completed the workflow to disable the CredSSP server.

Failed.message: The workflow to disable the CredSSP servers has been completed, but there was an error. {0}.

Completed.description: CredSSP client has been successfully disabled.
Completed.message: Completed the workflow to disable the CredSSP client.

Failed.message: The workflow to disable the CredSSP client has been completed, but there was an error. {0}.
The workflow to disable CredSSP has been completed, but there was an error. {0}.

Completed.message: Completed the workflow to disable CredSSP.

Gateway.description: Removing the CredSSP client role from the Windows Admin Center gateway so that it will not longer delegate credentials to the server.
Gateway.message: Removing the CredSSP client role from the Windows Admin Center gateway.

Server.description: Removing the CredSSP server role so the server can no longer receive credentials from the Windows Admin Center gateway.
Server.message: Removing CredSSP server role from server.

Completed.description: CredSSP server has been successfully enabled.
Completed.message: Completed the workflow to enable the CredSSP server.

Failed.message: The workflow to enable the CredSSP servers has been completed, but there was an error. {0}

Completed.description: CredSSP client has been successfully enabled.
Completed.message: Completed the workflow to enable the CredSSP client.

Failed.message: The workflow to enable the CredSSP client has been completed, but there was an error. {0}
The workflow to enable CredSSP has been completed, but there was an error. {0}

Completed.message: Completed the workflow to enable CredSSP.

Client.description: Disable the CredSSP client role so the Windows Admin Center gateway will not delegate credentials to the servers.

Gateway.description: Enable the CredSSP client role so the Windows Admin Center gateway can delegate credentials to the server.
Gateway.message: Configuring the Windows Admin Center gateway for CredSSP.

Client.description: Enable the CredSSP client role so the Windows Admin Center gateway can delegate credentials to the servers.

Server.description: Enable the CredSSP server role so the server can receive credentials from the Windows Admin Center gateway.

PatchLevel.description: For best security is is recommended that that latest CredSSP hotfixes be applied to your gateway.
PatchLevel.message: Checking the Window Admin Center gateway for the latest CredSSP hotfixes.

PatchLevel.description: For best security is is recommended that that latest CredSSP hotfixes be applied to your managed servers.
PatchLevel.message: Checking the server for the latest CredSSP hotfixes.

Starting.description: To enable CredSSP both a managed server and the Windows Admin Center gateway must be configured for thier appropriate role.

azureAd.firstRegister: To use Azure Active Directory, first register the gateway with Azure.
azureAd.tooltip: You must be a member of the local Users group to access the gateway server, even if you use Azure AD. Also, you can’t restrict the rights of local admins – they can do pretty much anything regardless.
azureAd.addDescription: Use Azure Active Directory to add a layer of security to the gateway
azureAd.title: Azure Active Directory

multiFactor.belongTo: {0} must belong to one of the following groups:
multiFactor.notEnabledFor: Multi-factor authentication is not enabled for {0}.
multiFactor.notEnabled: Not enabled. Multi-factor authentication requires a group that provides smartcard authentication.
multiFactor.title: Multi-factor authentication

multiFactorEnabled.tip: Because multi-factor authentication is enabled, {0} must also belong to one of the following secondary authentication groups:

access.adSuccessMessage: Successfully changed the identity provider to on-premises Active Directory and local groups - refresh this page to continue.
access.aadSuccessMessage: Successfully changed the identity provider to Azure Active Directory - refresh this page to continue.
access.manageNote: By default, all members of the Azure AD tenant can access the gateway, while only local administrators on the gateway system can administer the gateway.
access.saveWarning: After changing the identity provider, everyone using the gateway will have to refresh their browsers and sign in again.
access.manageStep3: On the Users and groups tab, select Add user, and then assign a role to each user or group you add.
access.manageStep2: On the Properties tab, set User assignment required to Yes.
access.manageStep1: Go to your SME Azure AD app in the Azure portal.
access.manageSubTitle: To limit access to specific groups:
access.manageDesc: By default, all members of the Azure AD tenant can access the gateway, while only local administrators on the gateway system can administer the gateway.
access.connectStep3: Refresh this page and enable the azure active directory option.
access.connectStep2: Open a PowerShell session and then run New-AadApp.ps1 -GatewayEndpoint <gateway-name>.
access.connectStep1: Download and extract the New-AadApp.ps1 script from​ this .zip file.
access.onPrem: On-premises Active Directory and local groups
access.learnMoreAboutControlling: How to control access to the gateway
access.learnMore: How to register a gateway with Azure
access.deleteConfirmation: Are you sure you want to delete {0}?
access.addSecurityGroupMessage: Groups in which SME checks for membership
access.description: Multi-factor authentication requires gateway users be in one of the allowed groups and authenticate with a secondary group, such as a group that provides smartcard authentication.
access.addGroupsDescription: Add groups to control who can access the gateway.

Errors.badFormat: Experiment keys must start with the extension name followed by the key. Example: 'msft.sme.shell.enableExperiment' where 'msft.sme.shell' is the shell extension and 'enableExperiment' is the key.

Experiments.description: Add experiment keys to turn on functionality that may not quite be ready for production environments. Experiment keys are case insensitive.
Experiments.label: Experiment Keys

Errors.badFormat: Side Loaded Extensions must start with either 'http://' or 'https://'

deleteDialog.message: This will remove the association between Windows Admin Center and the Azure AD app created when you registered the gateway. This will NOT delete the Azure AD app nor affect any Azure services currently used by servers managed by Windows Admin Center.
